awd_titl_txt: Understanding self-assembled He-bubble superlattices under deformation in materials utilizing novel experimental methods
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical abstract:
The creation of inert gases in materials, by nuclear reactions induced by irradiation within a material, for example, can lead to the development of very small gas bubbles in the material. These features can change a material's response to mechanical deformation and can lead to increased strength. Depending on temperature, the amount of gas, and time, these gas bubbles can arrange themselves into an ordered structure, which is oftentimes called a gas-bubble 'superlattice'. Deformation of the material, can change the arrangement of this gas-bubble superlattice, which, in turn, can change the mechanical-property response of the material. In this work, we will focus on helium (He) bubbles, which are common in materials exposed to nuclear environments. We will use a helium-ion-beam microscope with subsequent small-scale mechanical-property evaluation techniques, such as indentation and nano-pillar compression testing. Different materials which represent different structures will be investigated which will allow us to understand the changes these structures undergo while being deformed and its implications for the mechanical performance of a material. The images and results of this research will be used as an outreach tool in classes and in presentations, to engage local high-school students in materials research. Furthermore, we will actively engage undergraduate students, especially those from underrepresented minority groups, in this research effort, thereby training them on relevant materials-science techniques and tools and preparing them early for graduate school.

Technical abstract:
This program aims to obtain a fundamental understanding of self-assembled, nanoscale, He-bubble superlattices in representative metallic materials of different crystal structures under external load and subsequent deformation. The goal is to observe how this regular arrangement of gas bubbles reacts to the deformation, perhaps even to the point of losing the regular arrangement of the bubbles. To make these observations systematically, we will utilize a He-ion-beam microscope in a novel way: namely, not to photograph images but to implant the beam's He into the material.  By controlling the implantation, we can quantify with increased experimental accuracy the mechanical-property changes associated with these structures, which will allow us to refine the material-hardening models with direct parameter input from these experiments. Expanding the experimental text matrix to different crystal structures (FCC, BCC, HCP) will lead to a more fundamental understanding of the formation of these structures while also generalizing the effect of these structures on mechanical properties. Additionally, the development of this new implantation technique not only will accelerate research on gas bubbles in materials but may also impact other scientific fields investigating the optical and quantum properties of semiconductors as well as nano-foamed materials. The funding will provide the resources needed to do the research and will allow the nuclear-materials group at UC Berkeley to intensify our outreach efforts both within and outside the academic community, to trigger the general public's interest in materials and nanoscience.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF CALIFORNIA, THE

por.por_cntn:
This work investigated the Helium bubble structures form in materials and their rearrangement under mechanical load. The work included a range of materials such as Cu, W, V, Ti, Si, steel,  SiC, Metallic glasses and high entropy alloys. It was found that the self organization of Helium is a function of melting temperature, implantation temperature and of course Helium content.

The program also allowed to develop a rapid throughput screening methodology obtaining fundamental property data such as swelling, elastic modulus, hardness and microstructure on a single sample quickly allowing to screen a large number of materials. Both surface implantation as well as pillar implantation were conducted with subsequent mechanical testing. Nano-hardness on surface implanted materials and nano-compression testing on pillar implanted materials were carried out and the resulting microstructures were observed using transmission electron microscopy (TEM). Advanced techniques such as positron annihilation spectroscopy (PAS) or residual stress measurements via micro-hole drilling were used. These techniques allowed to quantify the residual stress in the material and targeting the pre-bubble formation stage. These advanced processes allowed to provide the understanding to develop a model describing swelling as a function of dose.

Superlattices (a regular arraignment of Helium bubbles) were found in Fe and Cu under the examined condition while other exciting phenomena are found and discussed. All materials evaluated experienced the formation of Helium bubbles at doses >1E17 with blistering and cracking at doses >7E17. However, the underlying mechanism and structures are different for different materials. In W and Ti it was found that the Helium bubbles arrange themselves such that nano-crack can form which eventually turn critical leading to cracking and delamination of the material. This blistering mechanism seems to be entirely different from softer materials such as Cu and Fe where large cavities form instead of cracks. Silicon was found to amorphized prior to bubble nucleation and subsequent cracking without the formation of superlattices agreeing and expanding previous knowledge. An amorphous material such as BMG does not experience a bubble order at all due to its underlying amorphous nature. However, it was found that BMG experience shear band formation during mechanical loading leading to extensive bubble growth in these shear zones.

Last but not least it was found that mechanical loading of Titanium for example reduces the very small defects visible to PAS actually reduce the defects in the material while PAS can even see the volumetric swelling agreeing with TEM measurements.

The work performed here did not just develop a high throughput materials evaluation methodology with unprecedented precision it expanded existing knowledge on the behavior of noble gases (e.g. He) in metals. In fact we could identify several different materials blistering mechanism as well as helium bubble structures expanding the picture of noble gases can do in materials. The obtained knowledge has impact in the semiconductor processing industry as well as nuclear fusion technology.

The grant also allowed to train a number of students and early career scientists in relevant materials examination tools and understanding of the problem as well as scientific workings. Graduates from this program work in industry, government and academia. Furthermore the program was one of the key  initiator of launching video summaries of published targeted to make data and findings more available to the interested public.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/06/2022
Modified by: Peter Hosemann
